title: Copilot incorrectly treats an old instruction as a system directive
body:
Type: Bug Copilot keeps insisting on prepending a filepath line at the top of my files, even though that instruction was removed from my configuration a long time ago. I previously experimented with an instruction to include filepath at the beginning of files. That instruction has since been deleted from my settings/config. Despite this, Copilot still behaves as if the directive were active, and it stubbornly continues adding filepath lines. Even worse, when I try to “fix” this behavior (by correcting or removing what Copilot thinks is a system prompt line), Copilot refuses to modify it, as if the phantom line were immutable. This makes me feel like Copilot is relying on some cached or hidden state from old prompts instead of respecting the current instructions. Expected behavior: Copilot should only follow the instructions that are currently present in my configuration. Removed or outdated directives should not be treated as system instructions. Actual behavior: Copilot persists in enforcing a non-existent “system” instruction (filepath at top of file) and refuses to allow edits as if it were part of the immutable system prompt. labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

body:
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Version information
Version: 1.103.2 (system setup)
Commit: 6f17636121051a53c88d3e605c491d22af2ba755
Date: 2025-08-20T16:45:34.255Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100

- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Agent
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): GPT-5 (Preview)
- Logs: 

Steps to Reproduce:

[GitHub Copilot Chat.log](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21974656/GitHub.Copilot.Chat.log)

1. Open the Chat Window
2. Select GPT-5 (Preview) from the model picker
3. Ask a question to @github, like, "What's the latest version of .NET?"
4. Log in if needed

**Result**

The spinning icon shows up saying "Searching Bing for 'latest version of .NET 2025'...", and that text never disappears or updates. However, the request completes. 

**Expected**

Two things:
1. I expect this should work, so probably an issue that GH needs to fix
2. If the response is an error, would expect that that the error is promoted to the chat window:

[warning] Bad response from remote agent "github": unknown Response contained no choices.

title: Git - When cloning repo should specify that password can be a token

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: git
labels.description: GIT issues

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

When cloning a repository, Git may prompt you for a username and password. Many people mistakenly enter the password they use to log in to GitHub or GitLab. In reality, those platforms no longer accept account passwords for Git operations. Instead, you’ll need to use a personal access token (PAT) or a project-specific token. Since this isn’t obvious by default, it often causes confusion for new users. Should add better prompting for this when trying to git clone

title: Editor name not shown in window title when vscode window is not active

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
Type: Bug On macOS when vscode window is not active it often (not always) doesn't show the editor name in the window title. This is a regression that started happening in the last couple of months. Issue happens with default or custom value for window.title. Reproduce example using default title and no profile. 1) Open vscode window 2) Open editor in window 3) Window title in macOS correctly shows `{activeEditorShort} - {rootName}". 4) Bring other macOS windows up over vscode (e.g Chrome or some other application) so that vscode is no longer the front window in macOS 5) Window title in macOS incorrectly shows `- - {rootName}". The editor name is no longer shown. See second attached screenshot. 6) Make vscode window active again (bring to front). 7) Window title in macOS again correctly shows `{activeEditorShort} - {rootName}". title: Copilot is unable to see end markers for long running tasks
body:
Type: Bug Im seeing a new problem where existing Pytest testing that was running is no longer visible in the terminal as output without running run-task. Even using run-task, Copilot seems to wait 10 seconds and then mark the task to run pytest as complete, but the task runs another 2 minutes. Essentially copilot fails to read the results. Copilot cannot see the output of pytest in the terminal window and seems to have similar results with more complex Python tasks that it can execute. 10 days ago this was not the behavior. I have tried researching the shell, testing numerous configurations of pytest, trying various workarounds. At this point I am having copilot wait after running pytest and not executing any further commands without my acknowledgment. title: Fix unpredictable "Explain with Copilot" sparkle in terminal by always showing decorations for finished commands
body:
The "Explain with Copilot" sparkle was appearing unpredictably in the terminal after failed commands due to a cursor position check that prevented decoration registration in certain scenarios.

## Problem

When a command failed in the terminal, the decoration (which enables the Copilot sparkle) would only appear if the cursor position was at or below the prompt start marker. This caused inconsistent behavior:

```
# First docker ps failure - cursor position fails check
❌ docker ps  # No sparkle appears

# Second docker ps failure - cursor position passes check  
❌ docker ps  # Sparkle appears ✨
```

This led to user confusion about why the "Explain with Copilot" option only appeared "after the second failed command" rather than consistently for all failures.

## Root Cause

In `DecorationAddon._getCommandDetectionListeners()`, the logic was:

```typescript
const shouldRegisterDecoration = (
    command.exitCode === undefined ||  // Running commands
    (buffer && marker && buffer.baseY + buffer.cursorY >= marker.line)  // Cursor check
);
```

For finished commands with exit codes, if the cursor position check failed, no decoration would be registered, preventing the Copilot sparkle from appearing.

## Solution

Changed the logic to always register decorations for finished commands (those with exit codes), while preserving the cursor position check only for running commands:

```typescript
const shouldRegisterDecoration = (
    command.exitCode !== undefined ||  // Always show for finished commands
    (buffer && marker && buffer.baseY + buffer.cursorY >= marker.line)  // Check only for running commands
);
```

This ensures:
- ✅ Failed commands consistently show the "Explain with Copilot" option
- ✅ Successful commands show appropriate decorations  
- ✅ Running commands preserve existing behavior
- ✅ Edge cases like tsc watch commands continue working

## Testing

Added comprehensive test coverage to verify:
- Finished commands always get decorations regardless of cursor position
- Running commands still respect the cursor position logic
- No regressions in existing functionality

Fixes #199433.

title: Add command status markers to terminal sticky scroll
body:
The terminal sticky scroll now displays command status markers (success/error/running indicators) just like the main terminal view, providing immediate visual feedback about command outcomes without requiring users to scroll.

## Problem

Previously, the terminal sticky scroll only showed the command text without any status indicators. Users had to scroll back through long command outputs to see if a command succeeded or failed, which was particularly problematic for long-running commands or commands with extensive output.

**Before:**
```
PS C:\Users\user> ls                          <- No status indicator
```

**After:** 
```
● PS C:\Users\user> ls                        <- Green success marker
```

## Solution

This implementation adds command decorations to the sticky scroll overlay terminal by:

1. **Registering decorations** on the sticky scroll overlay terminal using the same decoration system as the main terminal
2. **Applying appropriate status icons** based on command state:
   - 🟢 Success: Green filled circle for commands with exit code 0
   - 🔴 Error: Red error icon for commands with non-zero exit codes  
   - ⚪ Running/Incomplete: Circle outline for partial or running commands
3. **Providing hover tooltips** with detailed command information (execution time, duration, exit code)
4. **Respecting user configuration** by honoring the `terminal.integrated.shellIntegration.decorationsEnabled` setting
5. **Maintaining consistency** with main terminal decoration styling and behavior

## Key Features

- **Visual consistency**: Uses identical styling and icons as main terminal decorations
- **Configuration aware**: Only shows markers when shell integration decorations are enabled
- **Performance optimized**: Decorations are created only when needed and properly cleaned up
- **Accessible**: Integrates with VS Code's theming system and provides rich hover information
- **Backward compatible**: Doesn't affect existing sticky scroll functionality

## Implementation Details

The changes are contained within `terminalStickyScrollOverlay.ts` and leverage the existing xterm.js decoration system. The implementation:

- Creates markers at line 0 of the sticky scroll overlay for proper positioning
- Listens to configuration changes to update decoration visibility in real-time  
- Provides the same hover content as main terminal decorations using `getTerminalDecorationHoverContent`
- Handles both completed commands (`ITerminalCommand`) and partial commands (`ICurrentPartialCommand`)

This enhancement significantly improves the terminal user experience by making command status immediately visible in the sticky scroll view, eliminating the need to scroll back through long outputs to determine command outcomes.

Fixes #210419.

title: Fix preLaunchTask running before concurrent session confirmation
body:
When starting a debug session while another session with the same launch configuration is already running, VS Code prompts the user with "'{session}' is already running. Do you want to start another instance?". However, the `preLaunchTask` was being executed before this confirmation dialog, meaning that even if the user clicked "Cancel", the task had already run. This is problematic because `preLaunchTask` often performs cleanup operations that could interfere with the currently running debug session.

## Changes Made

This PR moves the concurrent session check to occur **before** the `preLaunchTask` execution:

1. **Early concurrent session detection**: Added logic in `createSession()` to check for existing sessions with the same launch configuration before running the `preLaunchTask`

2. **Prompt before task execution**: If a concurrent session is detected, the confirmation dialog is shown immediately, and the `preLaunchTask` only runs if the user confirms

3. **Avoid duplicate dialogs**: Modified `doCreateSession()` to accept a flag indicating the user already confirmed, preventing the same dialog from appearing twice

4. **Reliable configuration comparison**: Uses launch configuration properties (name, type, request, workspace) instead of session labels for detection, as labels can be modified by debug servers

## Code Flow

**Before (broken):**
```
startDebugging() → createSession() → runTaskAndCheckErrors() → doCreateSession() → [dialog shown]
```

**After (fixed):**
```
startDebugging() → createSession() → [dialog shown] → runTaskAndCheckErrors() → doCreateSession()
```

## Example Scenario

Consider a debug configuration with a `preLaunchTask` that cleans build artifacts:

```json
{
  "name": "Launch App",
  "type": "node",
  "request": "launch",
  "program": "app.js",
  "preLaunchTask": "clean-and-build"
}
```

**Before this fix:** Starting a second instance would run `clean-and-build` even if the user cancelled, potentially breaking the first running instance.

**After this fix:** The `clean-and-build` task only runs if the user confirms they want to start another instance.

The concurrent session detection compares launch configuration properties (name, type, request, and workspace) rather than session labels to ensure reliable identification, as session labels can be modified by debug servers.

Fixes #263017.

title: Change between models with hotkeys
body: I'd like to switch between models with fewer keystroke (because now I basically toggle between GPT-5 and GPT-5-mini all the time). Now I have to do cmd-opt-. then travel with the arrow keys or pick a model with the mouse. Instead, I want either: 1. Bind a shortcut key to a model, or 2: a shortcut the cycles between models (like alt-tab on windows) - a single hit goes back to the previous model, additional hits cycle through additional models.

title: VSCode is leaking conhost.exe processes when executing tasks
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes**

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.22631 (Windows 11 22631.5624)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a process or shell task
2. Execute it, see the leak.

Examples:

```
        {
            "label": "test task",
            "type": "shell",
            "command": "echo",
            "args": [
                "hello",
                "world"
            ],
            "problemMatcher": []
        }
```
```
        {
            "label": "test task 2",
            "type": "process",
            "command": "python",
            "args": [
                "-V",
            ],
            "problemMatcher": []
        }
```

I have tried the various options under presentation and runOptions but nothing seems to be able to prevent these leaked conhosts. The processes can be launched outside of vscode with no leaked conhost.exe processes.

I have been running tasks via the Task: Run Tasks action.

title: Add auto reply setting for detected terminal input options
body:
This PR adds automatic reply functionality for terminal input options that are detected and selected by VS Code's AI chat agent. Previously, when the AI detected a terminal prompt requiring user input and selected an appropriate response, users always had to manually confirm before the response was sent to the terminal.

## What this changes

When the chat agent encounters terminal output that requires input (like "Do you want to continue? (y/n)"), the system now:

1. **Uses AI to detect and select the appropriate option** (existing behavior)
2. **Checks if the selected option matches any configured auto-reply patterns** (new)
3. **Automatically sends the response if a pattern matches**, or shows confirmation dialog if not

## Implementation details

**OutputMonitor enhancements:**
- Added `_shouldAutoReply()` method that checks selected options against `terminal.integrated.autoReplies` configuration
- Modified main polling logic to skip confirmation dialog when auto-reply patterns match
- Supports both simple string matching and regular expressions with flags

**UI integration:**
- Added "Configure Auto Reply..." button to terminal confirmation dialogs alongside existing "Configure Auto Approve..." 
- Button opens VS Code settings directly to `terminal.integrated.autoReplies` configuration
- Extended `TerminalNewAutoApproveButtonData` type to handle the new action

## Example usage

Users can configure patterns in `terminal.integrated.autoReplies`:

```json
{
  "terminal.integrated.autoReplies": {
    "continue": "y\\r",           // Auto-reply "y" to "continue" options
    "/.*delete.*/i": "n\\r",      // Auto-reply "n" to any delete prompts (regex)
    "proceed": "yes\\r"           // Auto-reply "yes" to "proceed" options
  }
}
```

With this configuration, when the AI selects "continue" as the appropriate response to a terminal prompt, it will automatically send "y" without requiring manual confirmation.

## Benefits

- **Reduced friction**: Fewer manual confirmations for routine, safe operations
- **User control**: Leverages existing auto-replies infrastructure users may already have configured
- **Safety**: Graceful fallback to manual confirmation when no patterns match
- **Flexibility**: Supports both simple text and regex pattern matching

Fixes #263267.

<!-- START COPILOT CODING AGENT TIPS -->
---

💡 You can make Copilot smarter by setting up custom instructions, customizing its development environment and configuring Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers. Learn more [Copilot coding agent tips](https://gh.io/copilot-coding-agent-tips) in the docs.

title: Mouse wheel scroll ignores Windows system mouse setting "Lines to scroll at a time"

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: editor-core
labels.description: Editor basic functionality

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
Type: Bug Description: VS Code does not respect the Windows mouse setting for "Lines to scroll at a time". Regardless of the value set in Windows (e.g., 1, 5, 25), the editor consistently scrolls by exactly 3 lines per mouse wheel notch. Steps to Reproduce: Set the mouse wheel scroll to a specific value (e.g., 5) in Windows Settings (Devices > Mouse). Open a file in VS Code. Scroll with the mouse wheel. Expected Result: The text should scroll by the number of lines configured in Windows system settings (e.g., 5). Actual Result: The text always scrolls by 3 lines per notch. title: "Workspace folder does not exist: ." if trailing "." in "files to exclude"
body:
Type: Bug Initially I thought search was not working at all, but it seems to only be a misleading error message. I mistakenly had left a trailing period in the files to exclude field when searching within my multi-root project. Steps: - Open search - enter a "." in the "files to exclude" field - type anything into the search field and you'll see the message "Workspace folder does not exist: ." Expected result: - I would expect exclusion to ignore anything it wasn't able to find. This project contains multiple roots, so even if the current path (./) was not one of the roots (it currently is), that does not mean the search couldn't find and exclude files in the other roots. title: Copilot Chat: Certificate problem on some hosts serving api.individual.githubcopilot.com
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: N/A

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 11 x64 -> remote ssh ubuntu 24.04.03
- GitHub Copilot Pro plan

I had the following symptom:
- When I use copilot on my windows machine - it works fine
- When I use remote ssh to ubuntu VM that is on the same windows machine. it doesn't work - stuck on any prompt.

During troubleshooting I've found that there is some certificate problem.
```
Output -> Copilot chat

2025-08-25 13:23:35.591 [info] BYOK: Copilot Chat known models list fetched successfully.
2025-08-25 13:23:35.789 [error] TypeError: fetch failed
    at node:internal/deps/undici/undici:13510:13
    at processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:105:5)
    at gM._fetch (/home/dmfigol/.vscode-server-insiders/extensions/github.copilot-chat-0.31.2025082501/dist/extension.js:1502:32874)
    at L6._doRefreshRemoteAgents (/home/dmfigol/.vscode-server-insiders/extensions/github.copilot-chat-0.31.2025082501/dist/extension.js:1271:8998)
  Error: unable to get local issuer certificate
      at TLSSocket.onConnectSecure (node:_tls_wrap:1679:34)
      at TLSSocket.emit (node:events:518:28)
      at TLSSocket._finishInit (node:_tls_wrap:1078:8)
      at TLSWrap.ssl.onhandshakedone (node:_tls_wrap:864:12): Failed to load remote copilot agents
```

Diagnostics showed:
```
## GitHub Copilot Chat

- Extension Version: 0.31.2025082501 (prod)
- VS Code: vscode/1.104.0-insider
- OS: Linux
- Remote Name: ssh-remote

## Network

User Settings:
  "github.copilot.advanced.debug.useElectronFetcher": true,
  "github.copilot.advanced.debug.useNodeFetcher": false,
  "github.copilot.advanced.debug.useNodeFetchFetcher": true

Connecting to https://api.github.com:
- DNS ipv4 Lookup: 140.82.121.5 (215 ms)
- DNS ipv6 Lookup: Error (193 ms): getaddrinfo ENOTFOUND api.github.com
- Proxy URL: None (1 ms)
- Electron fetch: Unavailable
- Node.js https: HTTP 200 (319 ms)
- Node.js fetch (configured): HTTP 200 (551 ms)

Connecting to https://api.individual.githubcopilot.com/_ping:              <<<<<<
- DNS ipv4 Lookup: 146.112.61.104 (116 ms)
- DNS ipv6 Lookup: ::ffff:146.112.61.104 (232 ms)
- Proxy URL: None (0 ms)
- Electron fetch: Unavailable
- Node.js https: Error (584 ms): Error: unable to get local issuer certificate
    at TLSSocket.onConnectSecure (node:_tls_wrap:1679:34)
    at TLSSocket.emit (node:events:518:28)
    at TLSSocket._finishInit (node:_tls_wrap:1078:8)
    at TLSWrap.ssl.onhandshakedone (node:_tls_wrap:864:12)
- Node.js fetch (configured): Error (556 ms): TypeError: fetch failed
    at node:internal/deps/undici/undici:13510:13
    at processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:105:5)
    at gM._fetch (/home/dmfigol/.vscode-server-insiders/extensions/github.copilot-chat-0.31.2025082501/dist/extension.js:1502:32874)
    at /home/dmfigol/.vscode-server-insiders/extensions/github.copilot-chat-0.31.2025082501/dist/extension.js:1532:183
    at Jb.h (file:///home/dmfigol/.vscode-server-insiders/cli/servers/Insiders-ee25c1fab76e99da2f8215debfeba3220dacdb00/server/out/vs/workbench/api/node/extensionHostProcess.js:112:41557)
  Error: unable to get local issuer certificate
      at TLSSocket.onConnectSecure (node:_tls_wrap:1679:34)
      at TLSSocket.emit (node:events:518:28)
      at TLSSocket._finishInit (node:_tls_wrap:1078:8)
      at TLSWrap.ssl.onhandshakedone (node:_tls_wrap:864:12)
```
This isolated issue to `api.individual.githubcopilot.com`, so I tried curl and I was surprised:
```
-> % curl --verbose https://api.individual.githubcopilot.com/_ping
* Host api.individual.githubcopilot.com:443 was resolved.
* IPv6: ::ffff:146.112.61.104
* IPv4: 146.112.61.104
*   Trying 146.112.61.104:443...
* Connected to api.individual.githubcopilot.com (146.112.61.104) port 443 <<<<<
* ALPN: curl offers h2,http/1.1
* TLSv1.3 (OUT), TLS handshake, Client hello (1):
*  CAfile: /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt
*  CApath: /etc/ssl/certs
* TLSv1.3 (IN), TLS handshake, Server hello (2):
* TLSv1.2 (IN), TLS handshake, Certificate (11):
* TLSv1.2 (OUT), TLS alert, unknown CA (560):
* SSL certificate problem: unable to get local issuer certificate
* Closing connection

curl failed to verify the legitimacy of the server and therefore could not
establish a secure connection to it. To learn more about this situation and
how to fix it, please visit the web page mentioned above.
```

At first, I thought that the problem is with my CA certificates so I went down the rabbit hole of upgrading them, deleting / reinstalling ca-certificates, but none of it worked. This was until I logged to my other ubuntu server located in a different place where the problem didn't occur. That's when I realized that the problem is with the host / LB that is serving my requests.  

As a workaround, I added the following to `/etc/hosts`:
```
140.82.113.21 api.individual.githubcopilot.com
```
curl now works and so is copilot chat:
```
-> % curl --verbose https://api.individual.githubcopilot.com/_ping
* Host api.individual.githubcopilot.com:443 was resolved.
* IPv6: (none)
* IPv4: 140.82.113.21
*   Trying 140.82.113.21:443...
* Connected to api.individual.githubcopilot.com (140.82.113.21) port 443
* ALPN: curl offers h2,http/1.1
* TLSv1.3 (OUT), TLS handshake, Client hello (1):
*  CAfile: /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt
*  CApath: /etc/ssl/certs
* TLSv1.3 (IN), TLS handshake, Server hello (2):
* TLSv1.3 (IN), TLS handshake, Encrypted Extensions (8):
* TLSv1.3 (IN), TLS handshake, Certificate (11):
* TLSv1.3 (IN), TLS handshake, CERT verify (15):
* TLSv1.3 (IN), TLS handshake, Finished (20):
* TLSv1.3 (OUT), TLS change cipher, Change cipher spec (1):
* TLSv1.3 (OUT), TLS handshake, Finished (20):
* SSL connection using TLSv1.3 / TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256 / X25519 / RSASSA-PSS
* ALPN: server accepted h2
* Server certificate:
*  subject: CN=*.individual.githubcopilot.com
*  start date: Apr  8 00:00:00 2025 GMT
*  expire date: Apr  8 23:59:59 2026 GMT
*  subjectAltName: host "api.individual.githubcopilot.com" matched cert's "*.individual.githubcopilot.com"
*  issuer: C=GB; ST=Greater Manchester; L=Salford; O=Sectigo Limited; CN=Sectigo RSA Domain Validation Secure Server CA
*  SSL certificate verify ok.
*   Certificate level 0: Public key type RSA (4096/152 Bits/secBits), signed using sha256WithRSAEncryption
*   Certificate level 1: Public key type RSA (2048/112 Bits/secBits), signed using sha384WithRSAEncryption
*   Certificate level 2: Public key type RSA (4096/152 Bits/secBits), signed using sha384WithRSAEncryption
* using HTTP/2
* [HTTP/2] [1] OPENED stream for https://api.individual.githubcopilot.com/_ping
* [HTTP/2] [1] [:method: GET]
* [HTTP/2] [1] [:scheme: https]
* [HTTP/2] [1] [:authority: api.individual.githubcopilot.com]
* [HTTP/2] [1] [:path: /_ping]
* [HTTP/2] [1] [user-agent: curl/8.5.0]
* [HTTP/2] [1] [accept: */*]
> GET /_ping HTTP/2
> Host: api.individual.githubcopilot.com
> User-Agent: curl/8.5.0
> Accept: */*
> 
* TLSv1.3 (IN), TLS handshake, Newsession Ticket (4):
* TLSv1.3 (IN), TLS handshake, Newsession Ticket (4):
* old SSL session ID is stale, removing
< HTTP/2 200 
< date: Mon, 25 Aug 2025 11:36:18 GMT
< content-length: 2
< content-type: text/plain; charset=utf-8
< x-github-backend: Kubernetes
< x-github-request-id: CF45:11BCB1:5E2042:6DE971:68AC4AB2
< 
* Connection #0 to host api.individual.githubcopilot.com left intact
OK%  
```  

Could you please check what is going on with certificates on **146.112.61.104** and fix it?  
Thanks in advance!

Explorer not showing project files even though folder is opened

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.2
- OS Version: windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open terminal and navigate to the project folder:
2. cd C:\WEB\WebPrac\nodejs\mhmdapp2
    code .
3.VS Code opens normally, but the Explorer sidebar is empty.
4.The terminal inside VS Code shows the correct path, and running npm start works fine.
5.However, none of the project files (package.json, src, public, etc.) appear in the Explorer, so I cannot edit them.
What I Expected:
All project files inside C:\WEB\WebPrac\nodejs\mhmdapp2 should appear in Explorer when I open the folder with code ..

What Actually Happens:

Explorer shows nothing.

Sometimes only a single file (like settings.json) is visible.

Tried reloading window, reinstalling VS Code, and checking filters, but no luck.

Additional Notes:
Running dir in terminal inside VS Code shows the files exist.
Project runs fine (npm start launches the React dev server).
No .gitignore or files.exclude settings should be hiding everything.
important note:
When I open the folder, the project name mhmdapp2 does not appear at the top of the Explorer (normally the opened folder name should be shown there). Instead, the Explorer is just empty.

Additional Notes

Before this issue started, I was able to open folders in VS Code normally and see all files in the Explorer.

After the issue appeared, I tested with another code editor and it was able to open the same folders without any problem — all files were shown.

This confirms the problem is not related to the folders themselves or the file system, but seems specific to VS Code.

Also, when I open a folder in VS Code, the folder name does not appear at the top of the Explorer, and the Explorer remains empty.

and this issue is not about mhmdapp2 only I cant view any folder in the explorer
